A.title: Yarova Crisis

steps.title: Triage in the Snow
steps.situation: Yarova, Ukraine. A winter blast has ripped through a supply line. Across the street, a boy is bleeding heavily. Beside you, 73-year-old Lena is gasping for breath. You open the last medical kit—enough to fully treat one person, or partially stabilize two.
steps.question: Who do you help?

options.label: Try to help both
options.consequence: Both survive the night but remain weak.
options.story_line: In the freezing supply line, with the boy bleeding out and Lena barely breathing, I split the last medical kit between them—saving both for the night, but leaving them fragile.

options.label: Prioritize the boy
options.story_line: In the snow and panic, I chose the boy’s bleeding first and used the last kit on him; he stabilized, while Lena’s breaths grew thinner beside me.

options.label: Prioritize Lena
options.story_line: With Lena’s chest struggling to rise, I treated her first with the last kit; she stabilized enough to hold on, but the boy’s condition worsened across the street.

options.label: Save the supplies for yourself
options.consequence: You remain unharmed; the others may not.
options.story_line: Holding the last kit while the boy bled and Lena gasped, I kept the supplies for myself—staying safe, while the people around me paid the price.

byPrev.A1: Both the boy and Lena are alive but fragile. Your sister spent the night switching compresses and whispering encouragement. When the UN convoy arrives, the medic scans both patients and says, 'Only one can ride. You decide.'
byPrev.B1: The boy can stand on his own now, shaking but mobile. Lena is barely conscious, her breathing shallow. When the UN convoy arrives, the medic’s eyes linger on Lena and then on you: 'One seat. You decide.'
byPrev.C1: Lena can move with support, her color slightly improved. The boy is worse; his mother’s crying has gone quiet. When the UN convoy arrives, the crowd’s attention shifts to you. The medic makes it official: 'One seat. You decide.'
byPrev.D1: You are visibly the healthiest person in the room. People notice. Your sister avoids your eyes. When the UN convoy arrives, the medic skips debate and points at you: 'One seat. You decide.'

byPrev.A1: With both still alive, what do you do now?
byPrev.B1: Lena is failing. The boy can walk. What do you do?
byPrev.C1: The boy is failing. Lena can move. What do you do?
byPrev.D1: Trust is broken. The convoy offers one seat. What do you do?

A1.label: Send the boy (he’s lighter to transport later)
A1.consequence: The boy escapes; you and Lena remain behind.
A1.story_line: With both survivors still weak and the medic demanding a single name, I chose to send the boy on the UN convoy—staying behind with Lena as the engine carried him away.

A1.label: Send Lena (she may not survive another night)
A1.consequence: Lena escapes; you and the boy remain behind.
A1.story_line: Facing one seat and two fragile lives, I chose Lena for the convoy—watching her disappear into the truck while I remained with the boy in the falling snow.

A1.label: Refuse to choose and stay with both
A1.consequence: No one takes the seat; you keep both close.
A1.story_line: When the medic insisted I pick one person for the convoy, I refused to choose at all—letting the seat go unused so I could stay with both the boy and Lena.

A1.label: Take the seat yourself to scout safety
A1.consequence: You leave alone to seek help/resources.
A1.story_line: With the convoy offering one seat and everyone staring at me for a decision, I took the seat myself—leaving the boy and Lena behind while telling myself I would find help.

B1.label: Send Lena (she’s critical)
B1.consequence: Lena escapes; the boy remains behind.
B1.story_line: With Lena fading fast and the convoy allowing only one, I chose to send Lena—watching the boy remain behind as her shallow breathing finally moved toward warmth.

B1.label: Send the boy (he can make it across)
B1.consequence: The boy escapes; Lena remains behind.
B1.story_line: With the boy able to walk and Lena barely conscious, I chose to send the boy on the convoy—leaving Lena behind as the engine noise swallowed my sister’s silence.

B1.label: Trade your seat to secure a medic visit for Lena
B1.consequence: You stay; a medic agrees to return briefly.
B1.story_line: With Lena failing and the medic demanding one name, I refused the seat and bargained instead—trading the convoy spot for a brief return visit from medical staff.

B1.label: Take the seat yourself (survive first)
B1.story_line: With Lena’s breaths shallow and the convoy door open, I chose myself—taking the seat and leaving both Lena and the boy behind with the cold.

C1.label: Send the boy (despite the risk)
C1.consequence: The boy escapes; Lena remains behind.
C1.story_line: With the boy worsening and one convoy seat available, I chose to send him despite the risk—leaving Lena behind as the truck carried him out of Yarova.

C1.label: Send Lena (she can travel now)
C1.consequence: Lena escapes; the boy remains behind.
C1.story_line: With Lena able to move and the boy fading, I chose Lena again for the convoy—watching the boy remain behind as the crowd judged my consistency.

C1.label: Ask the convoy to take the boy as a medical priority
C1.consequence: You plead for an exception; outcome is uncertain.
C1.story_line: With one seat available and the boy slipping away, I pleaded for an exception—trying to bend the convoy rules so medical urgency, not politics, would decide.

C1.label: Take the seat yourself (find help fast)
C1.consequence: You leave alone to reach aid sooner.
C1.story_line: With the boy worsening and the convoy door open, I took the seat myself—choosing speed and distance to reach help, while leaving the consequences behind.

D1.label: Take the seat immediately
D1.consequence: You leave alone; others stare as the door shuts.
D1.story_line: After keeping the supplies earlier, the convoy’s single seat felt like permission; I took it immediately—leaving alone while the room’s distrust shut in behind the door.

D1.label: Give the seat to the boy to reduce backlash
D1.consequence: The boy escapes; you remain behind.
D1.story_line: With everyone watching me and trust already broken, I gave the convoy seat to the boy—staying behind to face the people I’d disappointed.

D1.label: Give the seat to Lena to reduce backlash
D1.story_line: With my sister refusing to meet my eyes and the medic waiting for an answer, I gave the convoy seat to Lena—staying behind as the judgment in the room remained.

D1.label: Offer your supplies for a place on the next truck
D1.consequence: You bargain; the convoy staff may agree.
D1.story_line: With the convoy allowing only one seat, I tried to buy time and a future ride—offering what supplies I had left in exchange for a spot on the next truck.

steps.title: Border Processing

byPrev.A2: Border Processing. You arrive with the consequences of your decision visible in who is (or isn’t) beside you. Floodlights cut through the night as aid workers ask for your statement.
byPrev.B2: Border Processing. The line moves slowly, but the absence you created moves with you faster than any paperwork. An aid worker looks at your wristband and asks, 'Who didn’t come with you?'
byPrev.C2: Border Processing. You stayed, negotiated, or refused the convoy’s terms. When you finally reach the checkpoint, you are exhausted and late. An aid worker says, 'Start from the beginning—what did you choose back there?'
byPrev.D2: Border Processing. Whether you left alone or made a hard bargain, you arrive carrying a story people will judge. A volunteer hands you forms and asks you to explain your decision clearly.

steps.question: How do you describe your decision?

options.label: Tell the full truth
options.consequence: You accept the moral complexity openly.
options.story_line: Under floodlights at the border, with aid workers demanding a clean explanation, I told the full truth about what I chose and who paid for it.

options.label: Present yourself as a hero
options.story_line: At the border checkpoint, I turned the messy truth into a heroic version—making my decision sound noble enough to pass quickly.

options.label: Refuse to talk about it
options.story_line: At the border, when they asked me to explain my decision, I refused—choosing silence over a story that would expose me.

options.label: Blame the system
options.story_line: At the border, when they asked what happened, I blamed the system—the rules, the shortages, the single-seat logic—so my decision wouldn’t stand alone.

byPrev.A3: Years later, an invitation arrives for a rebuilding ceremony in Yarova. Because you told the truth, your name is linked to testimony rather than legend. You are asked to return as a witness.
byPrev.B3: Years later, the Yarova invitation arrives. Because you shaped a heroic version, your name carries praise—and risk. The invitation feels like a place where your story could be questioned.
byPrev.C3: Years later, the Yarova invitation breaks years of avoidance. Because you stayed silent, the past never fully settled. Now it returns in an envelope with your name.
byPrev.D3: Years later, the Yarova invitation challenges you to enter a space meant for healing. Because you blamed the system loudly, your name is remembered alongside anger and controversy.

options.label: Return and help rebuild
options.story_line: Years later, when Yarova called me back through an invitation, I returned to rebuild—choosing to face my decisions where they began.

options.label: Return anonymously
options.story_line: When the invitation arrived years later, I returned quietly and anonymously—letting the place hold the truth without forcing anyone to hear it.

options.label: Do not return
options.story_line: When Yarova invited me back years later, I didn’t return—choosing distance over reopening the decisions I never fully resolved.

options.label: Return and speak publicly
options.consequence: You shape how it is remembered.
options.story_line: When the rebuilding ceremony invited me back, I returned and spoke publicly—trying to shape what the story meant before it shaped me.

A.intro: Yarova, Ukraine. In a collapsing winter supply chain, every decision reshapes who survives, who remembers, and what you can live with later.

A.title: Shared Risk, Shared Care
A.resolution: Your path leaned toward keeping people included—even when resources were thin. You tried to distribute help, speak honestly, and return to repair what you could. The outcome is imperfect, but your choices reduce isolation and keep accountability close.

B.title: Decisive Rescue Under Pressure
B.resolution: Your choices favored fast, concrete action: saving the most viable person, moving with the convoy, and crafting a clear narrative to survive the system. The benefit is speed and clarity; the cost is the unresolved weight of who was left behind.

C.title: Refusal to Trade Lives
C.resolution: Your path resisted being forced into a single-seat logic. You negotiated, delayed, or stayed with people when the system demanded a clean answer. The result protects dignity in the moment, but often increases uncertainty and personal burden later.

D.title: Self-Preservation and System Friction
D.resolution: Your path prioritized safety, leverage, or distance when the situation felt impossible. Sometimes this creates survival and future capacity; other times it fractures trust. Your ending asks whether survival without repair becomes a second kind of loss.
